passages.text: August 29, 2025 09:00 AM GMT
Affirm Holdings Inc (AFRM.O) Price Target
Strengthens our thesis Impact to our thesis
Meaningful upside Modest revision higher Financial results versus consensus Direction of next 12-month consensus EPS
Source: Company data, Morgan Stanley Research

WMT treatment proved to be a non- event in a goldilocks environment with Affirm surpassing even the most bullish of expectations. \(0\%\) adoption is attracting higher quality borrowers while Card is unlocking frequency & offline spend. Highly encouraged by the durability of growth but RR remains balanced

Affirm's GMV grew \(+43\%\) y/y, surpassing expectations of high- 30s, with the FY26 outlook in- line with street inclusive of WMT headwind \(0\%\) financing GMV rose to \(14\%\) of mix growing \(+93\%\) y/y; Affirm is using \(0\%\) as a strategic tool to attract higher FICO borrowers with lower credit risk Affirm Card GMV increased \(+132\%\) y/y to \(\) 1.2\(bn, is now used by 2.3mm users, and is proving to be a meaningful unlock of offline spend (+187\% y/y) Raising estimates and PT to\) \ \(90\) as \(0\%\) and Card are driving an inflection in and durability of growth

The perfect storm. The environment for Affirm continues to be nearly optimal- strong employment, good economic growth, relatively stable interest rates, and voracious appetite for private credit paper- supporting \(+43\%\) y/y GMV growth (vs. investor expectations of high- 30s and our consensus- matching \(+33\%\) y/y) which, in turn, benefited RLTc and AOI margin (27% vs. consensus of 24.4%). We are most encouraged by the ongoing mix shift to \(0\%\) financing- \(0\%\) GMV mix was \(14\%\) (+1pt q/q) and grew \(+93\%\) y/y vs. \(+44\%\) y/y in C1Q25- as even though greater mix of \(0\%\) tends to be a near- term drag on RLTc margins (we estimate that RLTc margins on \(0\%\) offers are \(\sim 3\%\) vs. the core interest- bearing product of \(\sim 5\%\) ), we continue to believe that the better borrower profile associated with \(0\%\) (management cited that users who exclusively use \(0\%\) have FICO scores 4Opts higher than the typical Affirm user) is value- enhancing and a key long- term growth enabler. While our estimates move modestly higher (see Exhibit 1), our estimates could prove conservative should the current environment (both from an employment, rate, and funding perspective) and inflection in key growth initiatives (e.g., Card, \(0\%\) , enterprise

merchant partners, etc.) persist. The most likely scenarios where we would look to become more constructive on the stock are: 1) market overreaction to normalization in key growth factors; and / or 2) if investors become overly concerned by the near-term financial impact of increasing mix to higher quality customers (which could come through greater mix of \(0\%\) promotions or lower rates on interest-bearing volumes).

- Monthly \(0\%\) APR adoption: GMV from \(0\%\) APR monthly installment loans grew \(93\%\) as the number of merchants funding \(0\%\) APR offers more than doubled to over 25,000 merchants. These merchants showed strong willingness to pay for such offers, with nearly \(95\%\) of GMV from \(0\%\) APR monthly installments at integrated merchants being funded by the merchant.- Affirm Card: Card GMV grew \(132\%\) to \(\) 1.2\(billion. Active cardholders grew\) 97\% \(to 2.3 million. In-store spend on Card grew\) 187\% \(. Card 0\% APR GMV more than tripled and now makes up about\) 14\% \(of Card GMV. Affirm also noted that on a TTM basis, card spend has increased from\) \ \(3,500\) to \(\) 4,700\(, progressing towards the company's target of\) \ \(7,500\) .- Credit risk: Affirm is intentionally using \(0\%\) promotions to attract higher FICO customers with lower credit risk. When weighted by amount spent, consumers that exclusively use \(0\%\) APR products have an average FICO score that is approximately 40 points higher than the average Affirm borrower. This shows up as less credit risk - in \(FQ4^{25}\) allowance rates for \(0\%\) APR loans were roughly \(60\%\) lower than those applied to interest-bearing loans.- Walmart native integration headwind: Affirm implied that Walmart (covered by Simeon Gutman) would be substantially transitioned by F2Q26. However, we would note that we continue to believe that at least \(33\%\) of Affirm's WMT GMV (which was \(5\%\) of GMV at the time of initial disclosure) will remain in place given the GMV originates on Affirm's own surfaces (Card and app).

Estimates increase modestly on the back of F4Q25 outperformance and constructive outlook; PIT to \(\) 90\(. We are raising our estimates across the board to account for recent outperformance and a view that growth durability is likely to persist as long as the employment and funding environment remain broadly stable (Exhibit 1). We are rolling our primary reference year to CY27, which, in addition to the \(3.5\%\) increase in our CY27 SBC- and warrant- burdened EPS, causes our price target to increase to\) \ \(90\) (vs. \(\) 70\() prior as we apply a\) 30x multiple to our revised Base Case CY27 SBC- and warrant- burdened EPS of \(\) 2.98\(. Note that based on our prior evaluation methodology (CY26 SBC- and warrant- burdened EPS), our\) \ \(90\) price target implies an approximate \(43x\) multiple (vs. \(34.5x\) prior), where we believe the increase in the absolute multiple should be viewed in context of an accelerating growth story that's becoming more durable (via \(0\%\) promotion unlock and Card growth). Further, we would note that our \(\) 90\(price target implies a\) 0.5x PEG (30x CY27 SBC- and warrant- burdened EPS multiple relative to a'25- '27 EPS CAGR of \(\sim 59\%\) ) vs. \(0.4x\) (34.5x CY26 SBC- and warrant- burdened EPS multiple relative to '25- '26 EPS growth of \(\sim 89\%\) ) previously.

- Overall eCommerce growth- Greater merchant acceptance- Expansion to international markets- New product launches- Rising competition- Credit risk and underwriting- Ability to move more of its portfolio of balance sheet- Regulation of BNPL market

- Faster e-comm growth and/or adoption of BNPL- Faster than expected rollout of Apple Pay- Faster than expected adoption of Affirm Card and credit products- Faster unlock of high-income consumers

- Credit deterioration/higher interest rates- Affirm access to capital is limited and funding costs rise faster- Competition pressures pricing- Key man risk associated with Max Levchin, founder and CEO

Morgan Stanley uses a relative rating system using terms such as Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated or Underweight (see definitions below). Morgan Stanley does not assign ratings of Buy,

Hold or Sell to the stocks we cover. Overweight, Equal-weight, Not-Rated and Underweight are not the equivalent of buy, hold and sell. Investors should carefully read the definitions of all ratings used in Morgan Stanley Research. In addition, since Morgan Stanley Research contains more complete information concerning the analyst's views, investors should carefully read Morgan Stanley Research, in its entirety, and not infer the contents from the rating alone. In any case, ratings (or research) should not be used or relied upon as investment advice. The Stock Ratings described below apply to Morgan Stanley's Fundamental Equity Research and do not apply to Debt Research produced by the Firm. For disclosure purposes only (in accordance with FINRA requirements), we include the category headings of Buy, Hold, and Sell alongside our ratings of Overweight, Equal-weight, Not-Rated and Underweight. Morgan Stanley does not assign ratings of Buy, Hold or Sell to the stocks we cover. Overweight, Equal-weight, Not-Rated and Underweight are not the equivalent of buy, hold, and sell but represent recommended relative weightings (see definitions below). To satisfy regulatory requirements, we correspond Overweight, our most positive stock rating, with a buy recommendation; we correspond Equal-weight and Not-Rated to hold and Underweight to sell recommendations, respectively.

Data include common stock and ADRs currently assigned ratings. Investment Banking Clients are companies from whom Morgan Stanley received investment banking compensation in the last 12 months. Due to rounding off of decimals, the percentages provided in the % of total' column may not add up to exactly 100 percent.

Overweight (O). The stock's total return is expected to exceed the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Equal-weight (E). The stock's total return is expected to be in line with the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Not-Rated (NR). Currently the analyst does not have adequate conviction about the stock's total return relative to the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Underweight (U). The stock's total return is expected to be below the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.
Unless otherwise specified, the time frame for price targets included in Morgan Stanley Research is 12 to 18 months.
Attractive (A): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months to be attractive vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.

In-Line (U): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months to be in line with the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below. Cautious (C): The analyst views the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months with caution vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below. Benchmarks for each region are as follows: North America - S&P 500; Latin America - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI Latin America Index; Europe - MSCI Europe; Japan - TOPIX; Asia - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI sub-regional index or MSCI AC Asia Pacific ex Japan Index.
